content: The "Subsidized Stafford Loan Reduced Interest Rate Extension Act of 2012" extends the reduced interest rate on Stafford loans until July 1, 2013. The "Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012" defines an "agency" as an executive agency under section 105 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 203. IMPROVING THE DETERMINATION OF IMPROPER PAYMENTS BY FEDERAL AGENCIES. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must annually identify high-priority Federal programs for increased oversight and establish targets for reducing improper payments. The Office of Management and Budget annually identifies high-priority Federal programs for increased oversight and sets targets for reducing improper payments. Agencies must report on high-dollar improper payments quarterly, detailing actions taken or planned to address them. The Inspector General assesses the risk and quality of improper payments in high-priority Federal programs, with a focus on recovery and prevention measures. Referrals to the Department of Justice are excluded from the report, but information can be shared with an Inspector General as required by law. The Inspector General evaluates improper payments in key federal programs, focusing on prevention and recovery measures. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will provide guidance to agencies to enhance improper payment estimates within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The guidance under the Improper Payment Information Act of 2002 aims to strengthen agency estimation processes by reviewing payment validity and accessing complete data. It also emphasizes ending reliance on self-reporting and developing a robust process to identify improper payments. To prevent improper payments, measures include recovering funds, analyzing employee pay data, addressing high-risk payments, and reassessing programs for better risk reflection. To prevent improper payments, measures include recovering funds, analyzing employee pay data, addressing high-risk payments, and reassessing programs for better risk reflection, including assessments for each program to reflect different risk components and direct corrective actions, and confirming proper inter-agency transfers using a methodology comparable to assessing program level improper payments. SEC. 204 of the Improper Payments Information Act of 2002 is amended to apply to fiscal year 2014 and onwards. SEC. 205 introduces the Do Not Pay Initiative. Each agency must review prepayment and preaward procedures to verify eligibility and prevent improper payments by checking databases such as the Death Master File, Excluded Parties List System, and Debt Check Database before releasing Federal funds. The Do Not Pay List includes databases like the Debt Check Database of the Treasury, Credit Alert System of HUD, and List of Excluded Individuals/Entities of HHS. It is established to prevent improper payments by agencies. The Do Not Pay List, established to prevent improper payments, includes databases assisting in this goal. Agencies have access to the list for payment eligibility determination. The Do Not Pay List helps prevent improper payments by providing databases for agencies to determine payment eligibility. An agency must recognize that there are circumstances where payments must be made to a recipient, regardless of their Do Not Pay List status. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to establish a plan for integrating other databases, providing agency access to the list, and creating multilateral data use agreements within specific timeframes. The Office of Management and Budget will establish a system for prepayment and preaward review, including the Do Not Pay List. The system will involve multiple agencies, fraud detection technologies, and commercial database sources for verifying Federal data. The Office of Management and Budget will establish a system for prepayment and preaward review, including the Do Not Pay List, involving multiple agencies, fraud detection technologies, and commercial database sources for verifying Federal data. Each agency must review all payments and awards for all programs through the system by January 1, 2013. Additionally, a plan for multilateral data use agreements, including access to databases like the New Hire Database under the Social Security Act, will be developed within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The agreements will adhere to protocols ensuring general security. Agreements must comply with data transfer and storage protocols, including relevant privacy and security laws such as HIPAA and section 552a of title 5, United States Code. The Attorney General shall consult with relevant agencies before implementing systems security requirements and developing a database of incarcerated individuals. The Attorney General will maintain a database of incarcerated individuals at Federal and State facilities, accessible to agencies to prevent fraud and updated weekly. Additionally, a plan will be established to improve the quality of death data held by the Social Security Administration in collaboration with stakeholders and States. The plan established under this subsection aims to improve the quality and frequency of access to death data maintained by the Social Security Administration. It includes actions for agencies to increase access, achieve daily access goals, and use electronic means for data provision. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget is required to submit a report to Congress within 120 days, including recommended legislation. SEC. 206 aims to improve the recovery of improper payments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget determines rates and amounts of recovery of improper payments, sets targets for recovery, and establishes at least 10 Recovery Audit Contracting programs within 90 days of enactment of the Act. Within 90 days of enactment, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes 10 Recovery Audit Contracting programs in 10 agencies to identify and recover overpayments and underpayments. 5 programs focus on reviewing commercial payments, with each program terminating within 3 years. Reports on program impact must be submitted to Congress within 3 months of completion. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes 10 Recovery Audit Contracting programs in 10 agencies to identify and recover overpayments and underpayments. Reports on program impact must be submitted to Congress within 3 months of completion, including recommendations on extending or expanding the program.
